Fig. 1 (a) Rate of the conversion of CO2 to methanol on ZnO/Cu(111) as a function of the fraction of zinc oxide coverage. Reaction conditions: temperature, 525, 550, or 575 K; H2, 4.5 bar; CO2, 0.5 bar. (b) Rate of the conversion of CO2 to methanol on 0.2 ML ZnCu(111) as a function of reaction time. Reaction conditions: temperature, 525 (circle) or 550 K (square); partial pressure of H2, 4.5 bar; and partial pressure of CO2, 0.5 bar. (c) Zn 2p3/2 XPS binding energies measured after reaction on the Zn/Cu(111) catalyst. Reproduced with permission [11] and copyrighted 2017, Science. (d-f) Experimental setup and XPS spectra under different gas environments. (d) The surface of Zn/ZnO/Cu(211) was probed with grazing incidence X-rays at different angles by exposure to a mixture of CO, CO2, and H2. (e) XPS spectra of the Zn 3d region collected at 453 K and ∼280 mbar on Zn/ZnO/Cu(211) at a varying gas mixture of H2:(CO + CO2) = 2.6:1 at a grazing incidence angle of 0.3°. Spectral raw data (circles) are deconvoluted by a four-peak structure. The green components at 9.53 and 9.85 eV correspond to the spin–orbit split components of metallic Zn 3d, the structure at 10.93 eV (gray) corresponds to ZnO, and the structure at 10.3 eV (light blue) corresponds to Zn in the oxidation state. (f) Same experiment as in (e) but with a grazing incidence angle of 0.9° to achieve greater bulk sensitivity. Schematic illustration of the reaction mechanism as dependent on the reaction mixture and conditions, which range from (g) CO-rich, reducing conditions to (h) medium conditions to (i) CO2-rich, more-oxidizing conditions, showing that the temperature and gas mixture critically affect the ZnO ⇌ Zn equilibrium. Reproduced with permission [25] and copyrighted 2022, Science. (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.) Fig. 2 (a) An aberration-corrected HRTEM image of Cu particles in the reduced Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst. (b) A close-up of the marked area in (a). Reproduced with permission [7] and copyrighted 2012, Science. (c) A HAADF-STEM image of the reduced Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst. (d) A representative HRTEM image of Cu/ZnO/Al2O3. The inset shows the corresponding line scans taken from the assigned regions of interest (ROIs). (e-g) Transformation from graphitic-like ZnOx to the wurtzite structure after electron beam exposures. The colors indicate different phases. Reproduced with permission [35] and copyrighted 2015, John Wiley and Sons. Fig. 3 (a) Changes in the formation rates of methanol over the CZA catalyst as a function of the CO2/CO ratio. (b) Zn LMM Auger signals of in situ XPS spectra of the CZA catalyst in a mixture of H2/CO/CO2 (493 K and 40 Pa) with different CO2/CO ratios. (c) Atomic ratio determined from the Cu 2p, Zn 2p, and Zn LMM Auger signals. (d) In situ CO-DRIFT spectra at 313 K on the CZA catalyst pretreated in H2/CO/CO2 mixtures (493 K and 100 kPa) with different CO2/CO ratios. Reproduced with permission [49] and copyrighted 2023, American Chemical Society. (e) Time-resolved Zn K-edge operando XANES spectra evolution during switching from H2 to a CO2/H2 gas reaction mixture at 15 bar and 533 K over CZA catalysts. (f) The relative fractions of wurtzite ZnO, Zn(HCOO)2 and CuZn alloy determined from PCA of the XANES spectra as a function of time after switching from H2 to a CO2/H2 mixture and back at 533 K and 15 bar over CZA catalysts. Reproduced with permission [30] and copyrighted 2020, Springer Nature. (g) Fourier transforms (FTs) of the k3-weighted Zn K-edge EXAFS after reduction to 773 K measured at different hydrogen pressures. Reproduced with permission [33] and copyrighted 2021, Springer Nature. (h) Genesis and transformation of the CZA precursor to the working catalyst. Reproduced with permission [84] and copyrighted 2022, John Wiley and Sons. (i-k) In situ XAFS investigations of the 1ZnO/Cu(OH)2 inverse catalyst under the conditions of CO2 hydrogenation at the Zn K edge. (i) Normalized XANES spectra and (j) FTs of EXAFS spectra of 1ZnO/Cu(OH)2 during CO2 hydrogenation under a pressure of 8 bar at different temperatures. The spectra of ZnO and Zn foil references are also shown for comparison. (k) First derivative of the Zn K-edge spectra of the 1ZnO/Cu(OH)2 inverse catalyst during CO2 hydrogenation at different temperatures. The peak at ∼9663 eV was assigned to the absorption edge of Zn by the 1s–4p transition. (l) Schematic illustration of the structural evolution of isolated ZnO to small aggregates with increasing temperature during either H2 reduction or CO2 hydrogenation reaction. The white, light yellow, light blue, purple and brown balls represent ZnO, oxygen-defective ZnO1-x, Cu(OH)2, partially reduced Cu(OH)2, and metallic Cu, respectively. Reproduced with permission from [50] and copyrighted 2022, John Wiley and Sons. (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.) Fig. 4 (a) Correlation of the H2-TPD and N2O-RFC results over a series of Cu-based catalysts with and without the addition of Zn. Reproduced with permission [39] and copyrighted 2014, John Wiley and Sons. (b) The change in the Cu surface area of CZA catalysts as determined by N2O-RFC, H2-TPD, and H2-TA after pretreatment at different partial pressures of H2 for 16 h. Reproduced with permission [32] and copyrighted 2014, John Wiley and Sons. (c) Catalytic performance of xZnO/Cu(OH)2 (x = 1, 2, 3, 6, 12 and 20), coprecipitated Cu-ZnO and commercial Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalysts in CO2 hydrogenation. (d) Correlations between methanol space–time yields and the number of oxophilic Zn sites, as determined by the difference between N2O titration and H2-TPD. Reaction conditions: temperature, 493 K; pressure, 45 bar; WHSV, 37600 mL⋅g−1⋅h−1. High-pressure pulse experiments (HPPEs) with NH3 poisoning. (e) Continuous dosing of NH3 with various concentrations under methanol synthesis conditions cofeeding with 1% ethane. The black, green, and blue curves represent the yields of methanol, ethane, and ethylene, respectively. (f) Switching experiments from CO/CO2/H2 to CO/H2 and back to CO/CO2/H2 at 483 K and 60 bar. The orange, blue and grey areas represent the Cu0 sites, Znδ+/ZnO sites, and Zn0 sites, respectively. Reproduced with permission [38] and copyrighted 2020, Springer Nature. (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.) Fig. 5 (a) A model of CuZn(211). The reddish-orange and gray balls represent Cu and Zn, respectively. Reproduced with permission [7] and copyrighted 2012, Science. (b) DFT-optimized geometries of HCOO* adsorption on CuZn(211). The brown, blue, gray, red, and white balls represent Cu, Zn, C, O, and H, respectively. Reproduced with permission [108] and copyrighted 2020, American Chemical Society. (c, d) A model of the inverse ZnO/Cu(111) interface (c) and DFT-optimized geometries for HCOO* adsorption (d). The light blue, red, brown, gray, and white balls represent Zn, O, Cu, C, and H atoms, respectively. Reproduced with permission [11] and copyrighted 2017, Science. (e-h) A model of the inverse ZnO/Cu(111) (e) and oxygen-vacant ZnO1-x/Cu(111) interfaces (g) and DFT-optimized geometries of HCOO* adsorption (f, h), respectively. ZnO/Cu(111) was modeled by decorating a one-layer (3 × 3)-ZnO(0001) ribbon on Cu(111), as adopted in previous literature [112] and recent advances [44]. To simulate oxygen-vacant ZnO, one-third of the interfacial oxygen atoms were removed. The brown, red, gray, black and white balls represent Cu, O, Zn, C and H atoms, respectively. (i) Microkinetic simulations of the activity of CO2 hydrogenation to methanol on Cu(111), CuZn(211), ZnO/Cu(111) and ZnO1-x/Cu(111). Mini-review Recent progress in understanding the nature of active sites for methanol synthesis over Cu/ZnO catalysts Xinyu Liu Writing – original draft Writing – review & editing a b Hengwei Wang Conceptualization Supervision Writing – original draft Writing – review & editing a ⁎ Junling Lu Conceptualization Validation Writing – review & editing a b ⁎ a Department of Chemical Physics, Hefei National Research Center for Physical Sciences at the Microscale, Key Laboratory of Precision and Intelligent Chemistry, University of Science and Technology of China, Hefei 230026, China Department of Chemical Physics Hefei National Research Center for Physical Sciences at the Microscale Key Laboratory of Precision and Intelligent Chemistry University of Science and Technology of China Hefei 230026 China Department of Chemical Physics, Hefei National Research Center for Physical Sciences at the Microscale, Key Laboratory of Precision and Intelligent Chemistry, University of Science and Technology of China, Hefei 230026, China b Suzhou Laboratory, Suzhou 215123, China Suzhou Laboratory Suzhou 215123 China Suzhou Laboratory, Suzhou 215123, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract Copper-zinc-alumina (Cu/ZnO/Al2O3) has been utilized as the leading catalyst for industrial methanol synthesis via hydrogenation of CO and CO2 for more than 50 years. Understanding the nature of active Zn sites at the atomic level is vital for gaining insight into the reaction mechanism and rational design of more efficient Cu/ZnO catalysts for methanol synthesis but remains greatly challenging and has been intensively debated for decades. In this mini-review, we first describe the fundamental insights obtained from well-defined model catalysts and then summarize the recent experimental evidence with respect to dynamic structural and electronic changes in the active Zn phase under realistic working conditions by in situ/operando microscopy/spectroscopy and surface site titration using probing molecules. In the following, we discuss the catalytic mechanism of diverse active structures by theoretical calculations and simulations. Therefore, the critical role of interfacial sites between metallic Cu and ZnO, especially those with oxygen defects, in methanol synthesis via CO2 hydrogenation is emphasized. Finally, we discuss the technical challenges and perspectives in understanding the origins of this Cu-ZnO synergy and rational design of next-generation Cu-based methanol synthesis catalysts. Keywords Methanol synthesis Cu-ZnO interface CuZn alloy In situ characterization Surface-site titration First-principles modeling Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction As an ideal fuel additive, a promising hydrogen carrier and a versatile building block for high value-added chemicals, methanol is one of the most attractive molecules for a sustainable economy, with a global consumption of approximately 107 million tons annually [1–4]. Industrially, since the 1960s, methanol has been produced from syngas (a mixture of CO, CO2, and H2; Eqs. (1) and (2)) at elevated temperatures of 473–533 K and pressures of 50–100 bar over Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 (CZA) catalysts. In particular, owing to the urgent need to mitigate the excessive emissions of anthropogenic CO2, direct catalytic hydrogenation of captured CO2 to methanol (Eq. (2)) using green hydrogen retrieved from renewable energy sources, so-called “liquid sunshine” [5], has recently received extensive attentions [2,6–16]. In addition to CZA, other catalysts in terms of supported metal catalysts, such as Cu/ZrO2 [12,13], Cu/CeO2 [14], Ni(Pd)-Ga [15,17], and Pd/ZnO [16], as well as oxide catalysts, such as In2O3 [18], ZnO-Cr2O3 [19], and ZnO-ZrO2 [2], have been gradually developed for the hydrogenation of CO/CO2 to methanol. Among these materials, Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 is still the leading catalyst in both academia and industry due to its higher activity, milder working conditions and lower costs. (1) CO + 2H 2 → CH 3 OH Δ 298 K = - 9 0 . 6 kJ / mol (2) CO 2 + 3H 2 → CH 3 OH + H 2 O Δ 298 K = - 49 . 5 kJ / mol Historically, commercialization of CZA catalysts has relied heavily on trial-and-error-based research. Although empirical laws for optimizing CZA have been determined in terms of Cu:Zn:Al ratio, pH, temperature, aging time, etc., namely, “chemical memory” [20,21], structure–performance relationships regarding the long-recognized synergy between Cu and ZnO species as well as rational guidance for designing highly efficient Cu/ZnO catalysts are still elusive. Empirically, the exposure of metallic Cu surface area was recognized as a guiding factor that positively correlated with methanol productivity in CZA catalysts [7,22,23]; however, this correlation could not explain the poor activity of supported highly dispersed monometallic Cu catalysts without the addition of Zn [24], strongly reflecting the importance of the synergistic effect of Cu-Zn on CZA catalysts [7,10,11,25–28]. Despite the strong demand and extensive efforts to optimize activity, the upgrading or even substitution of the currently commercialized CZA has been bottlenecked for decades. Consequently, a clear understanding of the synergistic effect of Cu and Zn, that is, the nature of active sites and the reaction mechanism at the atomic level, is highly desirable for the rational design of next-generation catalysts with higher methanol selectivity and yield, which continue to be enduring and attractive topics in both academia and industry. Numbers of research groups have contributed to this topic over the past decades by various physico-chemical approaches, including surface science investigations under ultrahigh vacuum (UHV) conditions [11,14,25,29], isotope-labeling transient kinetics analysis [24,30], in situ infrared (IR) spectroscopy [14,29,31], in situ or ambient pressure X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) [7,10,11,25,29,32], in situ/operando X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) [27,30,33,34], electron microscopy [7,35–37], scanning tunneling microscopy (STM) [14,29], neutron scattering [7], probe molecule titration [10,32,38,39], density functional theory (DFT) calculations and kinetic Monte Carlo (KMC) simulations [7,11,14,24,40]. However, after decades of intensive research on CZA catalysts, the chemical nature of active sites has remained controversial due to the intractable structural complexities of these materials, as well as their dynamic changes under realistic reaction conditions. Traditionally, metallic state Cu0 is widely believed to be a catalytically active component [7,41]. The lattice strain [7,42], surface morphology [43,44] and valence state [33,45] have been demonstrated to play important roles, as discussed in previous studies. While ZnO is more than just a structural promoter to prevent Cu from sintering and poisoning but also an active component that participates in reactions through strong synergistic effect with Cu. Disagreements mainly exist with regard to the nature of Zn sites in close contact with Cu0; these sites are intensively debated as metallic Zn0 in the form of a CuZn alloy phase [7,10,28,46] or as oxidative Znδ+ species at Cu/ZnO interfaces [11,47,48]. To date, the debate is still an enduring and attracting topic for the catalysis community [25,49]. The aforementioned grand challenges in identification of the active phase of Zn could stem from (i) very limited in situ/operando characterization techniques available for CZA catalysts, which typically operate above 473 K and 50 bar since adjustments to both high-temperature and high-pressure conditions and surface sensitivity are technically almost impossible for most characterizations [38]; (ii) challenging electron microscopic characterization owing to the close atomic weights of Zn and Cu, which could obstruct their identification from each other; and (iii) diverse structural and compositional heterogeneity of the ternary CZA catalyst (Scheme 1 a), where only a very small fraction of Zn species are in close contact with Cu0 in the complex CZA industrial catalyst, which could further impede in situ/operando spectroscopic characterization significantly [50]. These challenges motivate researchers to construct a catalyst model structure with a much clearer structure than that of the CZA catalyst while preserving appreciable catalytic performance in methanol synthesis. Well-defined Cu nanoparticles (NPs) supported on ZnO with uniform Cu-ZnO interfaces represent an alternative model for simplifying the complexity of the Cu-ZnO system and have made valuable progress in revealing the catalytic mechanism toward the Cu-ZnO interface [51,52] (Scheme 1b). However, the interference of the inactive ZnO in bulk to the investigations of interfacial sites can also be challenging. Compared to industrial CZA and supported Cu/ZnO model catalysts, inverse ZnO/Cu model catalysts (Cu-supported ZnO catalysts) have much higher fractions of Zn species adjacent to Cu (Scheme 1c), especially when the Zn species are highly dispersed, which could be beneficial for spectroscopic characterization while preserving high performance and attracting great interest in recent years. In this mini-review, we focus on recent studies on the understanding of the nature of active sites, particularly the active phase of Zn species, in methanol synthesis over Cu/ZnO catalysts. First, we describe the fundamental insights obtained from well-defined ZnO/Cu(111) model catalysts, a model structure of real CZA catalysts with simplified complexity. Then, we systemically summarize the experimental observations of enrichment of Zn species (ZnO overlayer or metallic Zn atoms) on the Cu NP surface and dynamic changes in their valence state (Zn0 or Znδ+) by either advanced electron microscopy or in situ/operando spectroscopy techniques. Next, we discuss the local structure of the active Zn phase by surface site titration techniques with NH3, N2O and H2 as probing molecules. Recent advances in the atomically precise synthesis of inverse ZnO/Cu real catalysts combined with multiple advanced characterization methods for understanding the nature of active sites at the atomic level are also discussed. Therein, we emphasize the critical roles of interfacial sites between metallic Cu and ZnO, especially those with oxygen defects, in methanol synthesis via hydrogenation of CO2. In the following, the catalytic mechanism under diverse active structures determined by theoretical calculations and simulations is further discussed. Finally, we discuss the technical challenges and perspectives in elucidating the origins of this Cu-ZnO synergy and rational design of next-generation Cu-based methanol synthesis catalysts. 2 Inverse ZnO/Cu model catalyst studies Model catalysis over single-crystal surfaces using surface science techniques has attracted wide interest in the field of heterogeneous catalysis since it provides the simplest systems with well-defined active centers compared to powder-based real catalysts. In the 1990s, surface science approaches were adopted to investigate the structural sensitivity of Cu catalysts for methanol synthesis on metallic Cu single-crystal surfaces, in which the more open Cu(110) surface was supposed to be more active than Cu(111) and Cu(100) [53,54]. By using in situ XPS combined with Auger electron spectroscopy (AES), Nakamura et al. demonstrated that the prominent promotion effect of adding Zn to Cu in CO2 hydrogenation to methanol was correlated with the Zn coverage on a metallic Zn-deposited polycrystalline Cu surface; wherein they proposed that the metallic Zn on the metallic Cu surface promoted methanol synthesis via CO2 hydrogenation. They also observed the formation of ZnOx species with a Zn:O ratio of approximately 1:1, as quantified by XPS after reactions, which was explained by the oxidation of Zn0 species by oxygen-involved intermediates during postreaction analysis [27,29]. In 2017, Kattel et al. [11] reported a direct comparison of Zn/Cu(111) and ZnO/Cu(111) inverse catalysts during CO2 hydrogenation to methanol at a total pressure of 5 bar using a combination of in situ XPS, DFT calculations and simulations. The methanol production rates showed a volcano-like trend as the ZnO coverage increased to Cu(111), with a maximum at 0.2 ML, regardless of reaction temperatures (Fig. 1 a), similar to the behavior observed by Nakamura et al. [27]. After the reaction, the high-pressure reaction cell was evacuated, and the single-crystal specimen was transferred to an ultrahigh vacuum chamber for XPS analysis. Interestingly, they found that the activity was initially low on the 0.2 ML Zn/Cu(111) surface and increased with reaction time until reaching values that matched with those reported on 0.2 ML ZnO/Cu(111) (Fig. 1b). Moreover, a clear upward shift in the Zn 2p3/2 peak position from ∼1021.1 eV (metallic Zn) to ∼1021.7 eV (ZnO) was simultaneously observed in XPS measurements (Fig. 1c). According to the activity variation together with the Zn phase transformation, the authors ascribed the active sites to Cu/ZnO interfacial sites, not CuZn alloy, which triggered a debate about the nature of the active Zn species [55,56]. As noted by Nakamura et al. [27], postreaction XPS analysis could result in misleading conclusions, in which the reaction intermediate (e.g., formate species) may decompose on the surface and subsequently oxidize the oxyphilic Zn0 to ZnO during the evacuation process [55]. It is thus suggested that a combination of C 1s and O 1s lines, or the use of the Zn Auger line by AES analysis, would be more reasonable for the determination of the chemical state of Zn via XPS measurements owing to the limitations of sensitivity in Zn 2p3/2 lines [32,55]. In addition, detecting model catalysts with more surface-sensitive techniques is highly desirable because active centers and reaction intermediates are often located at the uppermost atomic layer of the catalyst surface. To meet this challenge, very recently, Amann et al. [25] reported a high surface-sensitive ambient-pressure XPS experiment over Zn/ZnO/Cu(211) during CO/CO2 hydrogenation with a local high pressure and an extreme grazing incidence of incoming X-rays. In this study, both the reaction temperature (453 K) and pressure (180–500 mbar) were sufficiently high to ensure that the adsorbates would turn over rapidly without accumulating on the surface. The grazing incidence angle was tuned to achieve different surface sensitivities of ZnO/Cu(211) (Fig. 1d). At a grazing incidence angle of 0.3° and an effective probing depth of ∼1.4 nm, they showed that the metallic Zn component (in green) became dominant as the CO/CO2 ratio increased, while the ZnO component (in gray) became dominant as the CO/CO2 ratio decreased (Fig. 1e). In contrast, at a grazing incidence angle of 0.9° and an effective probing depth of ∼5.3 nm, which reflected the bulk information, there was no significant variation in Zn species under different CO/CO2 ratios (Fig. 1f). Benefiting from the tunable grazing angle, sufficiently high temperature and pressure, and the use of a more sensitive Zn 3d line rather than the Zn 2p line, the authors reported that the dynamic behavior of the oxidation state of Zn strongly depended on the composition of the CO/CO2 mixture (Fig. 1g–i); that is, under CO-rich conditions, ZnO transformed into Zn, forming CO2 and H2O (Fig. 1g). The addition of CO2 affected the ZnO-Zn equilibrium by oxidizing back to ZnO (Fig. 1h). In the absence of CO, most of Zn species were ZnO (Fig. 1i). According to the well-documented “volcano-like” trend reflecting methanol formation rates as a function of the CO/CO2 ratio over industrial CZA catalysts with a vertex at a ratio of ∼7.3 [49,57], the increase in metallic Zn0 with increasing CO/CO2 ratio observed here was consistent with the increase in the “volcano-like” trend but failed to explain the downhill side. Although the surface dynamics of Zn species were clearly demonstrated in this work, the correlations between activity and Zn species under different CO/CO2 ratios remain to be further clarified. Notably, besides the inverse ZnO/Cu model catalysts, Cu/ZnO model systems have been also extensively studied to simplify the structure of the industrial CZA catalyst for fundamental understanding. These studies have provided insightful understandings of the reaction mechanism in term of the particle size effect of Cu NPs [41,52,58] and the facet effect of ZnO support [59–62]. For example, de Jong et al. [41] reported that the surface-specific activity decreased significantly for Cu particles smaller than 8 nm regardless of the presence or absence of ZnO promoter. The authors proposed that the methanol synthesis reaction occurred at Cu surface sites with a unique configuration of atoms such as step-edge sites, which smaller particles cannot accommodate. However, Karelovic et al. [52] reported that the methanol formation rates normalized by surface Cu atoms were independent of Cu particle size in the range of 8.5 and 37.3 nm. On the contrary, the CO formation rates was enhanced on smaller Cu clusters. By mixing Cu NPs and ZnO with various morphology, Tsang et al. [59] demonstrated that the (002) polar facet of plate-like ZnO NPs showed a much stronger electronic interaction with Cu NPs than other facets and thus exhibited higher selectivity in the catalytic hydrogenation of CO2 to methanol. While on plate-like ZnO supported Cu catalysts, Ye et al. [60] observed a clear ZnO x overlayer on the Cu NPs and demonstrated that migration of ZnO x species to Cu NPs to form active interfacial sites should play vital roles for methanol formation from CO2 hydrogenation. In comparation to inverse ZnO/Cu model catalysts, the investigations on Cu/ZnO system provide valuable insights into the structure-sensitivity of Cu and the electronic interplay between Cu and ZnO support in methanol synthesis, revealing a synergistic effect between these two components. Nonetheless, it is worth noting that only a small fraction of Zn species is present near the Cu/ZnO interfaces in these samples as summarized in Scheme 1, which may impede efforts to investigate the nature of active Zn species through in situ/operando spectroscopic characterization. 3 Electron microscopic studies Regarding the CZA catalyst, Cu was mostly believed to exist in metallic NPs after reduction at 473–573 K, while the majority of Zn species were oxidized ZnO. Owing to the lower surface free energy of ZnO or Zn (90 or 990 mJ/m2) than that of Cu (1825 mJ/m2) [63], zinc species tend to migrate onto Cu NPs under reducing conditions at high temperatures, demonstrating the strong interplay between Cu and ZnO [64–67]. Electron microscopic characterization, including high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) and high-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM), is one of the most powerful tools for visualizing the morphology of heterogeneous catalysts directly and has provided informative evidence for revealing the above strong interplay between Cu and ZnO in industrial CZA catalysts [7,35,67,68]. In 2012, by using aberration-corrected HRTEM, Behrens et al. [7] reported that the inward curvature of the particle caused the presence of stepped surface facets, as well as defects such as stacking faults and twin boundaries (Fig. 2 a and b), which might be assigned to the active Cu0 sites for methanol formation. In addition to the stepped/defect Cu surface, the authors also observed the presence of disordered ZnO overlayers over Cu NPs with a thickness of 1 nm (Fig. 2a), whose atomic structure was neglected without further discussion. Later, in 2015, Willinger et al. [35] provided detailed evidence from HAADF-STEM. As shown in Fig. 2c, the disordered ZnO (in green) was 1–2 nm thick and presented a “graphitic-like” or “h-BN-like” layered structure with an interlayer distance of 0.18–0.28 nm (Fig. 2d), which is consistent with the DFT prediction and surface XRD observation of few-layer thin ZnO films [69]. Interestingly, the disordered ZnO layer was found to be metastable, and phase transformation was subsequently observed during exposure to electron beam, where the “graphitic-like” disordered ZnO gradually transferred to the ordered rock salt phase and finally transformed to the more crystallized wurtzite phase (Fig. 2e–g). The abovementioned earlier studies were all based on ex situ electron microscopy, which might be questioned by exposure to air. To exclude this issue, very recently, Willinger et al. [68] performed in situ TEM studies on CZA catalysts while the temperature was ramping from 293 to 773 K in H2 at 1 bar, and they found that small crystallized ZnO patches as well as disordered ZnO layers coexisted on the Cu NPs. The complex morphology as well as the dynamic evolution of the complex reflected the great challenges in characterizing the interplay between Cu and Zn species, which strongly depended on the operating conditions. However, the formation of the CuZn alloy phase has not been distinguished in the abovementioned characterization due to the relatively close atomic weights (Z) of Cu and Zn since the intensity in HAADF-STEM images is approximately proportional to Z2 [70]. In brief, extensive HRTEM and HAADF-STEM characterization both confirmed the surface enrichment of ZnO x on Cu NPs after reduction over CZA catalysts, demonstrating the strong interplay between Cu and Zn species. These dynamics could be ascribed to the strong metal-support interaction (SMSI) between Cu and ZnO, which has been observed on Cu/ZnO catalysts by using several surface-sensitive characterization methods [7,64–66]. In real catalysts, ZnO-overlayer fully covered Cu NPs coexist with partially covered and practically uncovered Cu NPs, in which the ZnO overlayers range from “graphitic-like” disordered structures to several crystallized ZnO patches or NPs. Attentions should be paid to identifying the structure of such overlayers because exposure of the reduced sample to either air or electron beam may cause disruptive structural transformation. Nevertheless, identifying the atomic structure at the interface regions between Cu and ZnO overlayers remains extremely challenging due to the very close atomic weights of Cu and Zn. Atomic-resolution electron energy loss spectroscopy (EELS) might be useful due to its element sensitivity. It is worth noting that the industrial CZA catalyst is also commonly employed for methanol steam reforming (MSR) reaction, which is the reverse reaction of methanol synthesis [71]. Interestingly, it has been observed that the catalysts undergo similar structural evolution during MSR reactions compared to those observed in methanol synthesis processes [72,73]. Very recently, Zhu et al. [73] provided clear evidence that exposing the CZA catalyst to a H2/H2O/CH3OH/N2 mixture at 573 K and atmospheric pressure could accelerate the migration of ZnO x species onto the surface of metallic Cu0 NPs via an adsorbate-induced SMSI effect by using energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) in STEM characterization. Combined with high-resolution EELS analysis, they demonstrated that the overlayers on metallic Cu NPs consist of non-stoichiometric ZnO x species, with Znδ+ (0 < δ < 2) species at the Cu–ZnO x interface and Zn2+ species inside the ZnO x . In addition, one should keep in mind that, either HRTEM or HAADF-STEM only represents a local region of sample with a two-dimensional (2D) projection along the direction of the incident beam and does not fully reflect the average structure of the whole sample or even the three-dimensional (3D) structure of the observed NPs (exposure of metallic Cu facets, distribution of overlayers, etc.). In situ/environmental TEM combined with atomic-resolution EELS and 3D reconstruction techniques might be the direction to overcome the above challenges, but the corresponding advances are still extremely limited. 4 Spectroscopic studies In situ or operando spectroscopic characterization techniques could provide macroscopic structural information of Zn species of working CZA catalysts at the atomic level. By using ambient pressure XPS, Behrens et al. [7] reported that the Cu:Zn ratio on the surface of calcined CZA decreased from ∼70:30 to ∼30:70 after reduction in H2, suggesting partial coverage of Cu NPs by ZnO x overlayers, in line with their HRTEM observation (Fig. 2a). Such dynamic changes in the surface composition of Cu/ZnO catalysts during activation in H2 have also been reported by ex situ XPS [74] and low-energy ion scattering (LEIS) [75]. However, it is not trivial to detect the occurrence of partial reduction from ZnO to metallic Zn during the dynamic change of ZnO x overlayers by XPS due to the small difference (less than ∼0.5 eV) between Zn2+ and Zn0 in the commonly used 2p line [32,55]. In contrast, the change in binding energy between Zn2+ and Zn0 was much more pronounced (∼3 eV) in the Zn L3M4.5M4.5 Auger peak, demonstrating a more sensitive behavior regarding the chemical state of Zn [76,77]. For example, Sehested et al. [32] observed a shoulder peak appeared at ∼3 eV downward shift of that of ZnO in the Zn Auger spectra of the industrial CZA catalyst under reduction at 10 mbar H2, which became more pronounced as the H2 pressure increased to 1 bar. By combination with O 1s, the Auger shoulder feature was attributed to metallic Zn0 [76], not to defective ZnO [77]; thus, they concluded that CuZn alloy was responsible for methanol formation over CZA catalysts. Compared to the above results obtained under a H2 atmosphere, Han et al. [49] recently reported the dynamic structural transition of Zn species in industrial CZA catalysts under reaction conditions. The authors found that methanol formation rates by feeding a mixture of CO/CO2/H2 were much higher than those feeding either CO/H2 or CO2/H2, which showed a “volcano-like” trend as the CO2/CO ratio increased (Fig. 3 a), in agreement with previous results by Pérez-Ramírez et al. [57]. By using in situ XPS in a flow of H2/CO/CO2 mixtures (493 K and 40 Pa), they also found that the Zn LMM Auger peak exhibited a shoulder feature at a lower BE of 4.3 eV with respect to that of ZnO (498.8 eV), indicating the presence of Zn0 on the surface (Fig. 3b), in agreement with previous results by Sehested et al. [32] The authors further quantified the surface fraction of Zn and Cu species by deconvoluting the Cu 2p, Zn 2p and Zn LMM Auger peaks. Interestingly, the authors found that the Zn2+ atoms enriched at the surface with a maximum Zn2+/Cu ratio and then decreased with the CO2/CO ratio (Fig. 3c), which adequately correlated with the characteristic volcano plot of the reactivity of methanol formation with the variation in CO2/CO ratios (Fig. 3a). In contrast, no similar trend was observed in the correlation between the variations in the Zn0 fraction and reactivity. Infrared spectroscopy with CO as a probing molecule is a surface-sensitive technique providing structural information about the topmost layer of metal catalysts and is commonly used for characterizing Cu/ZnO catalysts [78]. For example, Topsøe et al. [64] observed a large downward shift of the CO band from 2085 to 2067 cm−1 upon increasing the reduction temperature from 493 to 573 K on Cu/ZnO using in situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS). However, no band shifts were observed for Cu supported on either Al2O3 or SiO2. The authors suggested that these downward frequency shifts could be attributed to the formation of CuZn surface alloy through the migration of reduced zinc species from interfaces to the surface of Cu NPs. Wöll et al. [76] investigated the surface oxidation of brass(111) (CuZn alloy with Cu/Zn ratio of 9:1) single crystal under UHV conditions using Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR). They reported that both clean Cu(111) and brass(111) substrates exhibited a typical CO stretch frequency of 2071 cm−1, which upshifted to 2091 cm−1 when ZnO films were prepared on brass(111) by exposure to small amounts of O2, indicating CO adsorption at Cu/ZnO interfacial sites. In another study, Huang et al. [44] performed in situ CO-DRIFTS measurements at 123 K on a series of used ZnO/Cu inverse catalysts and quantified the ratio of surface Cu sites by fitting the CO adsorption bands. They assigned peaks centered at 2075 and 2060 cm−1 to CO adsorbed at metallic Cu0 and CuZn alloy [79], respectively, while excluding any existence of Cu-O-Zn sites according to the absence of peaks centered at 2130–2137 cm−1. Interestingly, they found that the methanol formation rate from CO hydrogenation is proportional to the amount of CuZn surface alloy, thus suggesting that CuZn alloy acts as an active site for the ZnO/Cu inverse catalyst to catalyze CO hydrogenation to methanol rather than Cu-ZnO interface. Recently, Han et al. [49] observed a low frequency CO stretching band at 2013 cm−1, which was assigned to both Cu-Zn2+ and Cu-Zn0 at the Cu/ZnO interfaces when exposed to a CO2-CO-H2 mixture on the CZA catalyst. They demonstrated that the intensity of this band increased to a maximum value and then decreased with further increases in the CO2/CO ratio (Fig. 3d), which also matched the trends of reactivity and the surface Zn (or Zn2+) fraction versus the reactant ratio (Fig. 3a and c). Consequently, the authors claimed that the Cu-Zn2+ interfacial sites favored methanol synthesis from a mixture of CO/CO2/H2 rather than Cu-Zn0 alloy over the industrial CZA catalyst. In brief, despite challenges associated with peaks ascription and analysis still existing [57,66,79,80], the CO-DRIFTS technique has offered extensive insights into the dynamic structural changes of Cu/ZnO catalysts and substantially deepened the understanding of the nature of active sites. XAS is a photo-in/photo-out characterization technique without any pressure restrictions and has been intensively employed in heterogeneous catalysis for obtaining element-specific structural information [81–83]. By using operando time-resolved XAS, van Bokhoven et al. [30] observed a variation in the oxidation state and the local environment of the industrial CZA catalyst in response to the reaction temperature and gas atmosphere. After reduction at 533 K and 15 bar H2, the authors observed that a characteristic preedge shoulder appeared at 9659 eV in the X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) spectrum of CZA at the Zn K-edge, which was assigned to metallic Zn0 in CuZn alloy. Once the pure H2 was switched to a CO2/H2 gas mixture at the same pressure, the preedge shoulder gradually decreased along with an increase of the main peak at 9669.2 eV, assigned to Zn2+ in ZnO, indicating the oxidation of Zn0 back to Zn2+ (Fig. 3e). Such dealloying by introduced CO2 was found to be more pronounced as the reaction temperature increased from 533 to 573 K, suggesting the instability of the CuZn alloy phase under these reaction conditions. By using principal component analysis (PCA) on the basis of spectra derived from a bulk standard of Cu0.66Zn0.33 alloy, zinc formate (Zn(HCOO)2), and ZnO, they further quantified the phase components of Zn to be ∼16 mol% of CuZn alloy and ∼2 mol% of surface Zn(HCOO)2, along with wurtzite ZnO at 533 K and a CO2/H2 mixture of 15 bar (Fig. 3f). After the reaction gas was switched back to H2, the fraction of Zn(HCOO)2 quickly vanished along with recovering of Zn0 to 25 mol%, resembling that of the initial state after H2 reduction. Very recently, the same group further investigated the effect of pressure on the dynamic transformation of both Cu and Zn phases during temperature-programmed reduction of the CZA catalyst by XAS measurements [33,84]. The XAS spectra were rapidly collected (1 Hz) in a single scan over four orders of magnitude in pressure (1 mbar to 10 bar) [33]. At the Cu K-edge, they found that the temperature at which Cu2+ was completely reduced to Cu0 decreased remarkably from ∼623 K to ∼473 K as the H2 partial pressure increased from 1 mbar to 1 bar and remained almost constant as the pressure further increased to 10 bar. In the case of the Zn K-edge, they found that the partial reduction of Zn2+ to Zn0 hardly occurred after reduction at 773 K with H2 pressure below 10 mbar but became far more pronounced with H2 pressure above 100 mbar (Fig. 3g). The reoxidation of reduced Zn also revealed a pressure dependence. After switching H2 to the CO2/H2 mixture, the fraction of Zn0 in CuZn alloy and Znδ+ in Zn(HCOO)2 both showed no appreciable changes at H2 pressures of 1 and 10 mbar, while dropped significantly as the pressure increased to 1 and 10 bar. According to the above comprehensive XAS investigations, the authors demonstrated that the reaction temperature, gas component, and especially the reaction pressure profoundly affected the dynamic transformation between Zn0 and Znδ+, indicating a substantial pressure gap regarding the structure of the Zn site between the working CZA catalyst and the Cu/ZnO catalysts characterized under low-pressure or UHV conditions. By combining steady-state isotope transient kinetic analysis and infrared spectroscopy (SSITKA-IR) with XAS, they determined the activation and working process of CZA catalysts, as illustrated in Fig. 3h. Initially, calcined CZA underwent CuO reduction in H2 below 420 K. After reducing above 450 K, the ZnO and Cu NPs started to grow larger, followed by CuZn alloy formation at above 500 K. After switching to CO2/H2 at 530 K, a dealloying process occurred due to the oxidative properties of CO2. In CO2 hydrogenation to methanol under different pretreatment conditions over industrial CZA catalysts, the authors found that the activity showed an inverse correlation with the fraction of Zn0; thus, proposed that the Cu-Zn2+ interfaces, rather than the unstable CuZn alloy, were the active sites for methanol formation from CO2 hydrogenation via a zinc formate intermediate route at a relatively high temperature and pressure [30]. It should be noted that the authors also noted that the feature of a lower energy shoulder in the Zn K-edge XANES region at 9656 ∼ 9660 eV (Fig. 3e), which was assigned to Zn0 in CuZn alloy, has also been found in oxygen-vacancy-rich bulk ZnO [85,86] and for other structural rearrangements in the ZnO phase [77]. Thus, mere analysis of the XANES data was insufficient to exclude the presence of defective ZnO, which was not quantified in the above studies due to the lack of a standard reference. Compared to industrial CZA catalysts, inverse ZnO/Cu model catalysts possess a significantly higher proportion of Zn species in close proximity to Cu, which could be beneficial for spectroscopic characterization [50,87,88]. Taking this advantage, we recently developed inverse ZnO/Cu catalysts by fabricating highly dispersed Zn species on copper hydroxide (Cu(OH)2) via atomic layer deposition (ALD) [50]. As an alternative to conventional wet chemistry methods, ALD provides a precisely controlled “bottom-up” approach in catalyst design owing to the unique feature of self-limiting molecular surface reactions, which favors the design and regulation of well-defined metal–oxide interfaces [89–95]. In our recent contribution [50], the size of ZnO on a Cu(OH)2 substrate was precisely controlled from atomically dispersed species to large NPs by tuning the number of ZnO ALD cycles from 1 to 20 (or ZnO coverage). The 1ZnO/Cu(OH)2 catalyst (consisting of one cycle of ZnO on Cu(OH)2) exhibited considerably high dispersion of Zn species as well as methanol formation activity, thus providing an exceptional platform for spectroscopic characterization. In situ XANES and FT-EXAFS spectra at the Zn K edge both showed that the ZnO species remained atomically dispersed below 393 K in CO2/H2 under a pressure of 8 bar (Fig. 3i and j). Increasing the reaction temperature to 433 K, isolated ZnO species appeared to aggregate to small ensembles, as indicated by the appearance of a new Zn-O-Zn multiple scattering peak at 9679 eV in the XANE spectrum (Fig. 3i) and a Zn-O-Zn coordination peak at 2.85 Å in the EXAFS curve in the real (R) space (Fig. 3j). Upon further increasing the reaction temperature to 493 K, the ZnO aggregations became more pronounced. The first derivatives of the XANES spectra were evaluated to highlight any subtle differences (Fig. 3k). We observed that the absorption edge at 9663 eV underwent a small shift to lower energy along with a weak pre-edge peak emerged at 9659 eV as the reaction temperature increased. Such local interferences in XANES strongly demonstrated the formation of defective ZnO, according to the literature [33,85,96]. Moreover, we did not observe any Cu-Zn coordination at an R value of ∼2.5 Å in the EXAFS spectra [33], in line with previous XAFS measurements, where Zn0 was not found at a reduction temperature below 510 K [97–100]. In brief, we demonstrated that highly dispersed ZnO was prone to aggregate into oxygen-deficient ZnO ensembles instead of forming CuZn alloys as metallic Zn during CO2 hydrogenation at 493 K (Fig. 3l), thus suggesting that the interface of metallic Cu0 NPs with oxygen-deficient ZnO rather than CuZn alloy is responsible for methanol formation from CO2. 5 Surface-site titration using probing molecules As a site-selective method, titration or chemisorption with probe molecules has been intensively applied in detecting and/or quantifying surface sites of heterogeneous catalysts [32,38,101–104]. Regarding Cu-based heterogeneous catalysts, N2O has been widely adopted as a probe molecule for determining the Cu surface area because it reacts with only the Cu0 atoms on the surface according to Eq. (3) with a stoichiometry of Cu:N2O of 2 due to its mild oxidizing ability [101,105]. (3) N 2 O + 2Cu s → Cu s - O - Cu s + N 2 By quantifying either the consumption of N2O or the formation of N2 via N2O reactive frontal chromatography (N2O-RFC) [101], N2O pulses [105], and N2O oxidation combined with H2-temperature-programmed reduction (s-TPR) [106], early studies showed that Cu surface area derived from N2O titration was positively correlated with the intrinsic activity of methanol synthesis [7]. However, such correlations might be questionable for understanding the active sites of CZA catalysts because they neglected the reducibility of ZnO in the presence of Cu. In recent years, many studies have shown that the presence of ZnO species in reduced CZA catalysts drastically affects the determination of exposed Cu surfaces by N2O titration due to the appreciable Cu–Zn interplay [10,32,39]. For example, Hinrichsen et al. [39] reported that the exposed Cu surface area derived from N2O-RFC was slightly greater than that obtained from H2-temperature programmed desorption (H2-TPD) (Fig. 4 a). According to the understanding that H2-TPD provided accurate determination of the exposed Cu0 surface sites [107], the authors proposed that N2O titration in fact probed the sum of surface Cu0 sites and the oxophilic Zn species (partially reduced ZnO, Znδ+, or oxygen vacancies at Cu/ZnO interfaces [32,76]), since the latter could also be oxidized by N2O, which was often neglected in early studies. In addition to oxygen vacancies, the abovementioned oxophilic Zn species were also ascribed to metallic Zn by several groups [7,10,32]. For example, Sehested et al. [32] observed a continuous increase in Cu surface area by N2O-RFC along with a decrease in H2-TPD as the H2 pressure increased for reduced CZA catalysts (Fig. 4b). According to the good correlation with the change in the Zn0 Auger peak area, they proposed that the deviation of the above two quantitative methods was attributed to the coverage of metallic Zn atoms on the Cu surface (denoted as θ Zn) during reduction. Furthermore, they showed a strong interdependency of methanol synthesis activity from syngas (CO/CO2/H2) and Zn coverage on Cu for industrial CZA, thus suggesting that CuZn alloy, formed by the reduction of ZnO to Zn0, was responsible for methanol synthesis [10]. Recently, we have found that inverse ZnO/Cu model catalysts with precisely-controlled dispersion of ZnO exhibited a volcano-like trend in methanol formation rate as a function of Zn content, reaching a maximum of 877 gMeOH⋅kgcat −1⋅h−1 along with a selectivity of ∼80% (on 3ZnO/Cu(OH)2 with a Zn content of 13.6 wt%). This performance was considerably superior to that of the Cu-ZnO binary catalyst synthesized by coprecipitation method with the same Zn content (Cu-ZnO-CP), and even comparable to that of the industrial CZA ternary catalyst (Fig. 4c) [50]. By combining H2-TPD and N2O-RFC titration methods, we established a good correlation between activity and surface structure over inverse ZnO/Cu model catalysts. Interestingly, we found that the methanol formation rates on these inverse catalysts were proportionally associated with the quantity of oxophilic Zn sites, as determined by the difference between the results of N2O titration and H2-TPD (Fig. 4d). According to our in situ XAFS characterization (Fig. 3i and k), wherein we observed the formation of oxygen-deficient ZnO x rather than CuZn alloy under reaction conditions, we demonstrated that the oxophilic Zn sites identified through titration analysis should correspond to Znδ+ (0 < δ < 2)sites of partially reduced ZnO, not metallic Zn as suggested by Sehested et al. [32], thus providing solid evidence that the interfacial sites of partially reduced ZnO1- x with metallic Cu act as active sites for methanol synthesis from CO2. Owing to the controversy on the assignment of oxophilic Zn sites to either Znδ+ or Zn0 using N2O and H2 as probe molecules, developing other site-sensitive techniques is still highly demanding. Very recently, Muhler et al. [38] adopted NH3, a weak Lewis base, as an alternative probe molecule since it was proposed to selectively poison the partially reduced Znδ+ site of Cu/ZnO interfaces (Lewis acid) instead of metallic Cu0 or Zn0. In high-pressure pulse experiments (HPPEs), they observed a reversible decrease in methanol productivity by injecting a trace amount of NH3 to the CZA catalyst under industrial reaction conditions (483 K, 60 bar, mixture of CO/CO2/H2), indicating the reversible blocking of the active sites by NH3 (Fig. 4e). When the reaction atmosphere was switched from CO2-containing syngas to CO/H2, the productivity loss became less obvious except for a temporary decrease induced by gas dilution, presumably due to the formation of metallic sites on catalyst surface (Fig. 4f) [25]. Accordingly, the authors proposed that the nature of the active sites strongly depended on the reaction conditions; that is, the Cu0-Znδ+ interfacial sites were active sites for industrial methanol synthesis over CZA catalysts, while the Cu0-Zn0 alloy formed in the CO2-free syngas CO/H2 and might dominate in the reaction of CO hydrogenation to methanol. 6 Theoretical modeling and kinetic simulations Theoretical modeling is a powerful approach for collaboration with experimental studies in this field. By calculating interactions between reactants/intermediates and substrates as well as the transition state structures of elementary steps during various reaction paths, theoretical modeling provides insights into the active sites and corresponding reaction mechanism, both thermodynamically and kinetically, and sheds light on the origins of the well-documented Cu–Zn synergy, thereby may guide the design or optimization of methanol synthesis catalysts. Extensive DFT calculations have been employed to determine the reaction kinetics at the CuZn alloy and Cu-ZnO interfaces. Studt et al. studied methanol formation on CuZn alloy by using a Zn-substituted Cu(211) surface, along with Cu(211) and Cu(111) (Fig. 5 a) [7]. The authors found that the Zn-substituted Cu(211) surface was much more active than both the Cu(211) and Cu(111) surfaces for methanol synthesis from either CO or CO2 via the formate pathway due to the much lower energy barrier. They claimed that alloying Zn atoms into steps of Cu NPs increased the adsorption strength of HCO, H2CO, and H3CO and decreased the reaction barriers, thus benefiting methanol synthesis from both CO and CO2. Kauppinen et al. [108] further demonstrated that the key intermediate formate was stabilized at the CuZn alloy surface by strongly binding to surface Zn atoms with bidentate Zn-O coordination (Fig. 5b). According to the DFT calculations from Studt et al. [24,109] for CO and CO2 hydrogenation to methanol, Delgado et al. [110] established a multiscale microkinetic model for methanol synthesis on the Zn-substituted Cu(211) surface (denoted as Cu/Zn(211)) and validated by extensive experimental data over the industrial CZA catalysts. They demonstrated that various factors, including the coverage of H (θH) and Zn (θZn) species on Cu surface and the accumulation of *CH3O and *OH species on Cu/Zn(211) surface, significantly influence the overall reaction kinetics for methanol synthesis, all of which are strongly dependent on variations in the CO2/CO ratio. Recently, Kattel et al. [11] compared the reactivity of CuZn surface alloy and inverse ZnO/Cu interfaces in methanol synthesis from CO2, which were modeled by a Zn-substituted Cu(211) stepped surface (ZnCu(211)) and a triangular Zn6O7H7 cluster-decorated Cu(111) surface (ZnO/Cu(111)) (Fig. 5c), respectively. The authors found that the formate pathway was more favorable than the reverse water-gas-shift (RWGS) followed with CO hydrogenation pathway for methanol synthesis from CO2, regardless of the type of active sites, as supported by the observation of only the *HCOO intermediate on the model surface. The hydrogenation of *HCOO (Ea = 0.85 eV) and *HCOOH (Ea = 0.90 eV) intermediates was the rate-limiting step on ZnO/Cu(111), which was much lower than that on ZnCu(211) (Ea = 1.49 eV). Therein, the formate intermediate adsorbed at the ZnO/Cu(111) interface by coordinating to the exposed Zn site of the Zn6O7H7 cluster rather than O atoms (Fig. 5d). KMC simulations further showed that the activity of ZnO/Cu(111) was one order of magnitude higher than that of ZnCu(211), and the coverage of O* on ZnCu(211) continuously increased during CO2 hydrogenation and reached a plateau after 15 min, in agreement with the experimental results (Fig. 1b and c). Consequently, by combining in situ XPS, DFT calculations and KMC simulations, the authors proposed that ZnO at the Cu/ZnO interface, rather than metallic Zn in the CuZn alloy, was more likely the active site for CO2 hydrogenation to methanol. Very recently, Han el al. reported similar results by considering Zn/Cu(111) and ZnO/Cu(111) with either a smaller triangular Zn3O3 cluster or a Zn3 cluster on Cu(111) [49]. They found that the Cu-Zn2+ interfacial site favored methanol synthesis via CO2 hydrogenation compared with the Cu-Zn0 sites because of the lower potential energies for both intermediates and transition states. Although oxygen vacancies derived from partial reduction of the Cu–ZnO interfaces have been found in various experimental studies, as discussed in the above sections, theoretical calculations have rarely been performed. To evaluate the roles of interfacial oxygen defects, we compared four surface models (Cu(111), CuZn(211), ZnO/Cu(111) and ZnO1- x /Cu(111)) for CO2 hydrogenation in our recent contribution, in which the stoichiometric ZnO/Cu interface (ZnO/Cu(111), Fig. 5e and f) and the oxygen-vacant interface (ZnO1- x /Cu(111), Fig. 5g and h) were both considered, as observed by in situ XAFS (Fig. 3i–k) [50]. We found that the adsorption of activated H* was rather weak for CuZn(211) (−0.05 eV) but too strong for ZnO/Cu(111) (−0.75 eV) with oxygen-terminated interfaces due to the formation of strong O–H bonds; moreover, the adsorption of CO2* at these two sites was much weaker of −0.23 and −0.03 eV, respectively. Such unfavorable adsorption made the subsequent hydrogenation kinetically less favorable via the formate pathways on both CuZn(211) and ZnO/Cu(111). In contrast, we found that the oxygen-vacant ZnO1- x /Cu(111) interfaces were highly active for methanol synthesis via the formate pathway due to the considerably strong adsorption of CO2* (−0.56 eV) at the exposed Zn site at the interfaces and the moderate adsorption of H* at the same Zn sites (−0.16 eV) or Cu sites (−0.22 eV) nearby. To quantify the intrinsic activity on the structural motifs constructed, we further conducted microkinetic simulations under the conditions of CO2:H2 = 1:3 at a pressure of 45 bar in the temperature range of 400–670 K, according to the experimental conditions (Fig. 4c and d). Here, all reaction pathways, including CO2 hydrogenation to methanol via the formate pathway or RWGS followed by CO hydrogenation, were unbiasedly included in the kinetic calculations. We found that the activity at the oxygen-vacant ZnO1- x /Cu(111) interface was much more active than those at the Cu(111), CuZn(211), and ZnO/Cu(111) interfaces over the entire temperature range considered (Fig. 5i). Accordingly, we provided the first evidence that oxygen-vacant ZnO1- x /Cu interfacial sites could be the catalytic active sites in methanol synthesis from CO2, rather than both CuZn alloy and the stoichiometric ZnO/Cu interface, agreeing perfectly with the approximately linear correlation between methanol formation rates and the number of oxophilic Zn sites (Fig. 4d). Interestingly, we found that the formate intermediate favored binding at the interface of the exposed Zn atom and adjacent Cu atom at the oxygen-vacant ZnO1- x /Cu interface (Fig. 5h), similar to the mechanism of adsorption at the interfaces of Zn x O y clusters with Cu [11,49,111], further implying that Zn termination (or the formation of oxygen vacancies) at the Cu/ZnO interfaces plays essential roles in methanol formation from CO2. In brief, by combining an atomically dispersed inverse model catalyst, high-pressure in situ XAFS and thorough DFT calculations of various structures, we moved a step forward to identify partially reduced ZnO1- x /Cu interfaces as the active site in methanol synthesis from CO2, providing deeper insight into the nature of active sites at the atomic level than the previous views of either ZnO/Cu interfaces or CuZn alloys. 7 Conclusion and outlook Although CZA has been the leading catalyst for industrial methanol synthesis from syngas for more than 50 years, identifying the nature of the active sites and understanding the reaction mechanism at the atomic level are still fascinating topics but remain extremely challenging due to intractable structural complexities, as well as dynamic changes under realistic reaction conditions. With the rapid development of experimental characterization techniques and theoretical calculations in recent years, great progress has been made in deepening our understanding to the atomic level. In this minireview, we focus on recent developments with respect to the understanding of the nature of active sites in methanol synthesis over Cu/ZnO catalysts and discuss them in five aspects: (1) surface science studies on inverse ZnO/Cu model catalysts; (2) strong interplay between ZnO and Cu observed by electron microscopy; and (3) dynamic changes identified by in situ spectroscopy. (4) surface active sites identification and quantification by titration with probe molecules. (5) reaction mechanism revealed by theoretical modeling and kinetic simulations. According to the above advances, ZnO would move to the surface of Cu NPs due to strong SMSIs under reaction conditions. The ZnO species in close contact with Cu NPs could be further reduced to defective ZnO or metallic Zn depending on the reaction temperature, pressure, and composition of the feed gas. Although the nature of the active Zn sites is still under debate, recently, more evidence provided by high-temperature in situ spectroscopy, site-selective titration and unbiased theoretical calculations tends to reach a consensus that oxophilic Znδ+ species at the Cu/ZnO interfaces, likely oxygen-vacant ZnO1- x , are responsible for methanol formation, especially from CO2 hydrogenation rather than metallic Zn in CuZn alloys. Accordingly, we propose that increasing the amount of defective interfacial ZnO but not forming metallic Zn should be an effective way to upgrade the current CZA catalyst. Indeed, Krossing et al. [113] reported a 1.6-fold increase in methanol formation rate along with an increase in selectivity from 59.4% to 71% in CO2 hydrogenation over Cu/ZnO binary catalysts through surface fluorination to introduce additional oxygen vacancies [113–115], strongly validating the essential role of oxygen vacancies in methanol formation. Moreover, inspired by the recent findings that altering the thickness of oxide patches onto metal NPs can substantially modulate metal-oxide interactions and consequently enhance their catalytic performance [17,88], particular attention should be given to the size effect of ZnO patches in inverse ZnO/Cu model catalysts compared to Cu/ZnO models, which might offer new opportunities for the design of a highly efficient methanol synthesis catalyst. In addition to the above progress, we note that challenges remain in the following three aspects: (1) Bridging the pressure gap and material gap. Regarding methanol synthesis over industrial CZA catalysts, high pressures (50–100 bar) are always required to shift thermodynamic equilibria and reaction kinetics toward methanol, thereby increasing efficiency and productivity and reducing cost. Moreover, the dynamic structural and compositional changes in active centers have been found to be strongly related to the activation and reaction pressure, which in turn prominently shapes the reactivity [30,33]. These challenges may result in a considerable discrepancy between the structural information gained from in situ and operando studies applied under mbar or UHV conditions and that in the working catalyst, namely, the long-recognized issue of the “pressure gap” and “material gap” [33], which are often heavily entangled in this field. Although model catalysis based on surface science techniques (XPS, STM, etc.) has achieved substantial progress, the technically realizable pressure range is currently restricted to below ambient pressure (hundreds of mbars), which leaves plenty of room for improvement. XAS, as a photo-in/photo-out technique without any pressure limitations, holds promise for disclosing structural information much closer to that of a real working catalyst. Developing high-pressure, operando XAS near working conditions (∼50 bar) provides direction to bridge these pressure and material gaps. (2) Developing surface-/site-sensitive techniques It is highly desirable to detect structural information only on the uppermost layer of the catalyst surface, which is essential for minimizing interference from the bulk of Cu and ZnO. Developing surface-sensitive techniques, such as grazing incidence spectroscopy with a tunable incidence angle [25] and synchrotron radiation photoelectron spectroscopy with tunable photoenergy, should be useful. Owing to the difficulty in identifying Cu and Zn atoms with similar atomic weights via HAADF-STEM, elemental-sensitive analysis, such as atomic resolution EELS elemental mapping [116], might be useful. Moreover, the disruption of metastable structures, such as poorly crystallized ZnO overlayers by high-energy electron beam should be considered. Although FTIR or DRIFTS characterization using CO as a probing molecule has been applied to identify the chemical state of Zn, for example, metallic Cu0-Zn0 [44,80,117], disagreements still exist regarding the assignment of CO vibration peaks due to their strong dependence on the structure, morphology and local environment of the Cu surface [49]. Site-selective poisoning by NH3 holds promise for the site-selective identification of Zn species under working conditions owing to the greater affinity of NH3 for Znδ+ than for Zn0 [38]. However, this approach is not trivial for quantification due to the reversible adsorption of NH3 at oxophilic Znδ+ species. Thus, more site-selective probe molecules with moderate Lewis basicity, which interact with a specific Zn site with sufficiently strong binding, should be further developed for quantification. (3) Understanding the reaction mechanism at the atomic level. In situ IR has been widely utilized to investigate the reaction mechanism by identifying the key intermediates for methanol synthesis in Cu-based catalysts [30,118–120]. High-pressure IR could be a powerful tool to bridge the pressure gap by increasing the coverage of key intermediates, thus in turn strengthening the intensity of corresponding IR signals. From the perspective of theoretical modeling, given the complex structure of CZA, neither ZnO clusters nor one-layer ZnO ribbons could unambiguously represent real ZnO ensembles in close contact with Cu0 in the working catalyst. Extended models based on experimental characterization should be developed to obtain unbiased calculations. Finally, the exploration of the nature of Cu/ZnO interfacial sites will continue in the future, and the efforts of the catalysis community will not stop here. We hope that this mini-review will inspire more valuable research in this field, and accelerate the development of advanced approaches, and ultimately the clarification of the long-standing debate in the near future. coredata.dc:description: Copper-zinc-alumina (Cu/ZnO/Al2O3) has been utilized as the leading catalyst for industrial methanol synthesis via hydrogenation of CO and CO2 for more than 50 years. Understanding the nature of active Zn sites at the atomic level is vital for gaining insight into the reaction mechanism and rational design of more efficient Cu/ZnO catalysts for methanol synthesis but remains greatly challenging and has been intensively debated for decades. In this mini-review, we first describe the fundamental insights obtained from well-defined model catalysts and then summarize the recent experimental evidence with respect to dynamic structural and electronic changes in the active Zn phase under realistic working conditions by in situ/operando microscopy/spectroscopy and surface site titration using probing molecules. In the following, we discuss the catalytic mechanism of diverse active structures by theoretical calculations and simulations. Therefore, the critical role of interfacial sites between metallic Cu and ZnO, especially those with oxygen defects, in methanol synthesis via CO2 hydrogenation is emphasized. Finally, we discuss the technical challenges and perspectives in understanding the origins of this Cu-ZnO synergy and rational design of next-generation Cu-based methanol synthesis catalysts.
